Description.val:
This budget line funds Modifications of In-Service Equipment to the Tactical Wheeled Vehicle fleet to include trailers and enablers. It is used to develop material solutions and also to procure hardware, materials, and the hardware installation cost required to complete the modification. Modifications are performed to correct safety deficiencies; increase mission capabilities and interoperability; extend the useful life; improve supportability; upgrade existing technology; increase efficiency; improve readiness; address obsolescence issues; and to meet new and/or changing statutory and regulatory requirements. By modifying existing equipment, the Army maintains a ready, supportable inventory of equipment that meets current requirements and regulations at a cost considerably below that of buying new equipment.

This line funds the Army's plan to recapitalize Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) RG33L+ variant vehicles originally bought to fill Operational Needs Statement (ONS) or Joint Operational Needs Statement (JUONS) into Program of Record (PoR) Panther Medium Mine Protected Vehicle (MMPV) Type I (a 6X6 vehicle).  In addition, this line implements the Army's plan to upgrade a mix of ONS/JUONS vehicles: Husky, Panther-MMPV Type I, Buffalo, and RG31-MMPV Type II (a 4X4 vehicle) in conjunction with a reset program to field PoR vehicles to Engineer Companies; Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear, Explosive (CBRNE) Units; Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) Units; and Area Clearance Platoons.

The Family of Heavy Tactical Vehicles (FHTV) modification effort includes, but is not limited to, upgrades to the Palletized Load System Trailer (PLST) with Container Transfer Enhancement (CTE). The CTE enables the PLS truck to directly transload a standard 20-foot International Organization for Standardization (ISO) container to the M1076 PLS trailer without the need for a M1077 flatrack. In addition, this line funds the United States Army Europe (USAREUR) Operational Needs Statement (ONS #17-22207) for Heavy Equipment Transporter System (HETS) tractor modifications.  It utilizes the existing M1070A1 HETS tractor to meet the payload screen and road transportability benchmark and provides the best cost, delivery schedule and risk rating.  Per the 1 DEC 17 Army Requirement Oversight Committee (AROC), the USAREUR HETS ONS solution shall ultimately be capable of carrying 85 tons of payload and receive road permits at 75 tons within the European Union.  Modifications to the tractor will allow the use of the HETS Urban Survivability Kit (HUSK) armored cab if operational conditions change.  This line can also fund modifications for active safety; autonomy; and Modification Work Orders (MWOs).

Justification.val:
FY 2019 Base procurement dollars of $69.452 million supports the fielding of 268 Husky, Buffalo, Panther, and Medium Mine Protected Vehicle Type II (Recapped RG-31) and required spare parts. Funds the Husky Engineering Change Proposal (ECP)  to provide the ability to Lift and Tie down the Husky vehicle for transport. This ECP is an Operations and Sustainment Cost Savings initiative since currently  the Husky requires a crane for disassembly and containerization. Funds Interim Contractor Logistic Support (ICLS) for previously fielded vehicles until validated  maintenance manuals are available and  Field Level Maintenance / New Equipment Training (FLMNET) is provided. In FY19 the fielding teams will provide FLMNET to 36 units.  Funds Program Management Support for the Product Office. The DA0924 split between DA0925 and DA0926 is 85% (DA0925) and 15% (DA0926) across both OCO and Base. The reason for the fluctuation between FY 17 and 18 is that in FY 17 all of the OCO funding was under DA0925 and this resulted in a lower percentage in DA0926 which made it look like installation cost in FY 18 increased when in reality it stayed the same as a percentage of total cost.

FY 2019 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $3.613 million funds the procurement of 110 kits and 262 installs of the Container Transfer Enhancement (CTE) for Heavy Tactical Vehicle's Palletized Load System Trailers (PLSTs).  CTE equipment provides Army commanders with the flexibility they need to respond to rapidly shifting operations by supplying the capability to transport critical cargo in order to support a versatile and expandable distribution system. 

FY 2019 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $5.442 million provides for 8 United States Army Europe (USAREUR) Heavy Equipment Transporter Systems (HETS) Operational Needs Statement (ONS) Tractor Modifications to pair with commercial new production trailers.  Per the 1 DEC 17 Army Requirements Oversight Committee (AROC), this additional modification to the tractor will allow it to achieve an ultimate carrying capacity of 85 tons while achieving host country road permits at a weight of 75 tons.  

FY 2019 OCO procurement dollars of $186.000 million supports the Army's plan for recapitalization-production of 236 Medium Mine Protected Vehicle Type II MMPV Type II (AAO 919). Procurement of GFE, which includes: Objective Gunner Kits, Drivers Vision Enhancement, Vehicle Internal Communication and A kits for radios, Blue Force Tracker, Defense Advanced Global Positioning System Receiver, jammers, chemical alarms. Equipment Costs which include Multi-functional Video Displays,  Interrogator Arm, Robot Deployment System and Vehicle Protection kits. The DA0924 split between DA0925 and DA0926 is 85% (DA0925) and 15% (DA0926) across both OCO and Base. The reason for the fluctuation between FY 17 and 18 is that in FY 17 all of the OCO funding was under DA0925 this resulted in a lower percentage in DA0926 which made it look like installation cost in FY 18 increased when in reality it stayed the same as a percentage of total cost.

FY 2019 OCO procurement dollars in the amount of $0.377 million provides for the hardware and installation of 21 CTE Kits on PLS trailers in support of the Combatant Command (COCOM) requirement for unit equipment sets to deter potential adversaries and support the European Deterrence Initiative (EDI) in outfitting the pre-positioned equipment sets.

SEPM includes PM and System Engineering oversight required to manage the program and contractors. Salaries, Benefits, Travel, Personnel Training and other Government costs are included for retaining a professional acquisition workforce. 

In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

Title.val: Family of Heavy Tactical Vehicles MOD Efforts

Description.val:
This line funds the Army's plan to recapitalize Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) RG33L+ variant vehicles originally bought to fill Operational Needs Statement (ONS) or Joint Urgent Operational Needs Statement (JUONS) into Program of Record (PoR) Panther Medium Mine Protected Vehicle (MMPV) Type I (a 6X6 vehicle).  In addition, this line implements the Army's plan to upgrade a mix of ONS/JUONS vehicles: Husky, Panther-MMPV Type I, Buffalo, and RG31-MMPV Type II (a 4X4 vehicle) in conjunction with a reset program to field PoR vehicles to Engineer Companies; Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear, Explosive (CBRNE) Units; EOD Units; and Area Clearance Platoons. 

The Family of Heavy Tactical Vehicles (FHTV) modification effort includes, but is not limited to, upgrades to the Palletized Load System Trailer (PLST) with Container Transfer Enhancement (CTE). The CTE enables the PLS truck to directly transload a standard 20-foot International Organization for Standardization (ISO) container to the M1076 PLS trailer without the need for a M1077 flatrack. In addition, this line funds the United States Army Europe (USAREUR) Operational Needs Statement (ONS #17-22207) for Heavy Equipment Transporter System (HETS) tractor modifications.  It utilizes the existing M1070A1 HETS tractor to meet the payload screen and road transportability benchmark and provides the best cost, delivery schedule and risk rating.  Per the 1 DEC 17 Army Requirement Oversight Committee (AROC), the USAREUR HETS ONS solution shall ultimately be capable of carrying 85 tons of payload and receive road permits at 75 tons within the European Union.  Modifications to the tractor will allow the use of the HETS Urban Survivability Kit (HUSK) armored cab if operational conditions change.  This line can also fund modifications for active safety; autonomy; and Modification Work Orders (MWOs).

FY 2019 Base procurement dollars of $57.758 million supports the fielding of 268 Husky, Buffalo, Panther, and Medium Mine Protected Vehicle Type II (Recapped RG-31) and required spare parts. Funds the Husky ECP to provide the ability to Lift and Tie down the Husky vehicle for transport. This engineering change proposal  (ECP) is an Operations and Sustainment Cost Savings initiative since currently  the Husky requires a crane to disassemble and containerize for transport then a crane to re-assemble at new location. Funds Interim Contractor Logistic Support (ICLS) for previously fielded vehicles until validated  maintenance manuals are available and  Field Level Maintenance / New Equipment Training (FLMNET) is provided. In FY19 the fielding teams will provide FLMNET to 36 units.  Funds Program Management Support for the Product Office. The DA0924 split between DA0925 and DA0926 is 85% (DA0925) and 15% (DA0926) across both OCO and Base. The reason for the fluctuation between FY 17 and 18 is that in FY 17 all of the OCO funding was under DA0925 this resulted in a lower percentage in DA0926 which made it look like installation cost in FY 18 increased when in reality it stayed the same as a percentage of total cost.

FY 2019 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $2.219 million funds the procurement of 110 kits of Container Transfer Enhancement (CTE) for Heavy Tactical Vehicle's Palletized Load System Trailers (PLSTs).  CTE equipment provides Army commanders with the flexibility they need to respond to rapidly shifting operations by supplying the capability to transport critical cargo in order to support a versatile and expandable distribution system. 

FY 2019 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $5.442 million provides for 8 United States Army Europe (USAREUR) Heavy Equipment Transporter Systems (HETS) Operational Needs Statement (ONS) Tractor Modifications to pair with commercial new production trailers.  Per the 1 DEC 17 Army Requirements Oversight Committee (AROC), this additional modification to the tractor will allow it to achieve an ultimate carrying capacity of 85 tons while achieving host country road permits at a weight of 75 tons.  

FY 2019 OCO procurement dollars in the amount of $0.377 million provides for the hardware and installation of 21 CTE Kits on PLS trailers in support of the Combatant Command (COCOM) requirement for unit equipment sets to deter potential adversaries and support the European Deterrence Initiative (EDI) in outfitting the pre-positioned equipment sets.

FY 2019 OCO procurement dollars of $157.400 million supports the Army's plan for recapitalization-production of 236 Medium Mine Protected Vehicle Type II MMPV Type II (AAO 919). Procurement of GFE, which includes: Objective Gunner Kits, Drivers Vision Enhancement, Vehicle Internal Communication and A kits for radios, Blue Force Tracker, Defense Advanced Global Positioning System Receiver, jammers, chemical alarms. Equipment Costs which include Multi-functional Video Displays,  Interrogator Arm, Robot Deployment System and  Vehicle Protection kits. The DA0924 split between DA0925 and DA0926 is 85% (DA0925) and 15% (DA0926) across both OCO and Base. The reason for the fluctuation between FY 17 and 18 is that in FY 17 all of the OCO funding was under DA0925 this resulted in a lower percentage in DA0926 which made it look like installation cost in FY 18 increased when in reality it stayed the same as a percentage of total cost.
